Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Vectors of Health: Science and the Making of Modified Mosquitoes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Aedes aegypti rose to international notoriety most recently for transmitting the Zika virus, causing a disease linked to babies born with microcephaly and other health issues. This insect species is also a vector for other viral diseases, including dengue, chikungunya, and urban yellow fever. The geographical expansion of the vector A. aegypti and the interconnectedness of the planet are all matters that increase the concern about mosquito-borne diseases in global attempts to govern and secure life. In the wake of the Zika outbreak, the World Health Organization endorsed pilot implementations of modified mosquitoes as a new vector control tool. The project, which trains a student in the methods of empirical, scientific data collection and analysis, explores several such pilot efforts to modify A. aegypti. Further, it would broaden the participation of groups underrepresented in science, build capacity and scientific infrastructure through international scientific cooperation, and enhance public scientific understanding by broadly disseminating findings to organizations engaged in public health policies for mosquito-borne diseases.

Luisa Castro, under the supervision of the Dr. Stepfan Helmreich of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, will explore different models of modifying A. aegypti, with the aim of evaluating whether different scalar approaches impact understandings of health outcomes and anthropogenic processes. International and local media marked Brazil as the epicenter of the 2016 Zika epidemic. In the last years, the country has also been struggling with dengue, chikungunya, and yellow fever outbreaks. However, these diseases are not only a problem for endemic countries like Brazil. This research will be conducted in different regions in Brazil, in order to ethnographically investigate three scientific projects that strive biologically to modify A. aegypti in order to deploy them to control local populations of these insects. Each project implements a different type of modification: one infects A. aegypti with the Wolbachia bacterium to curtail the mosquito's ability to transmit viruses; the other irradiates the mosquito to sterilize it; and yet, a third genetically engineers the mosquito to limit its reproduction. By accompanying researchers and workers in their daily practices between lab and field, the researcher will collect data on the efforts to develop these technologies, and the imaginaries and justificatory logics that surround their implementation. Person-centered interviews, a technique used frequently in psychological anthropology, among a sample of 60-75. She will also investigate how modified mosquitoes conform and rearrange Brazilian policies for controlling mosquito-borne diseases, historically oriented around human behavioral reforms and toxic chemicals. Being attentive to the professional experiences and training of those involved in these projects, she will also observe how scientists, lab workers, and government officials assess methodologies, formulate theoretical engagements, and frame their political positions and personal aspirations in their goal to transform research into health applications. This project proposes to trace the confluence of natural, scientific, and political agendas, practices, and strategies, particularly in the context of diseases. It will provide specificity to analytical reflections on social-cultural drivers of anthropogenic processes and the solutions proposed to mitigate their effects. The project aims to develop a historically-informed critical theory of health around mosquito-borne diseases that takes seriously the environmental dynamics, politics, and social power relations that inform these interactions. In times of growing anxieties about mosquito-borne diseases, and burgeoning solutions of how to control them, an ethnographically rich account can contribute to debates to develop more comprehensive, reflective, and effective policies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
I have conducted fieldwork, archival research, and interviewed people in different cities in Brazil. My research stay is the basis for my dissertation and I already envision four chapters, in addition to introduction and conclusion. The first chapter examines the Wolbachia-infected mosquito project I accompanied in Rio de Janeiro, asking questions about (multispecies) labor, precarity within the dismantling of public healthcare system and research institutions, and challenges of implementing a project in a city marked by violence. The second analyzes matters of science and public health policies in relation to the irradiated mosquito project developed in the city of Recife and in the island of Fernando de Noronha, investigating how mosquitoes, workers, and the environment are imagined as infrastructure that enables and limits the success of the endeavor. Another chapter will zero in on vector control projects being developed at the triple border (Brazil, Argentine, and Paraguay) inquiring the relations between nationalism and science, particularly in a moment in Brazil where nationalistic imaginaries and austerity measures increasingly define the relationship between state and science. The fourth chapter will address questions about “Brazilian” science drawing in particular from interviews I conducted with policy makers in Brasília and fieldwork in different national scientific (entomology, tropical medicine, medical veterinary, virology, etc.) meetings.

During my time in Rio de Janeiro I worked together with scholars from different departments at Fiocruz to organize two workshops. The first one, Global Health: Zika epidemic and international intersects, mapped and examined the various scientific, political, and institutional narratives about “global health” related to Zika. During the meeting, researchers from different universities and multiple disciplines offered a multifaceted reflection of the meanings and reverberations the Zika epidemic had for global/public health efforts and international scientific researches. The second workshop was organized as part of ABRASCO, the annual conference of the collective health association, and it was called Zika Epidemic in Brazil: Lessons learned and Recommendations. It brought together scientists, policy makers, and stakeholders (in particular the associations of families/mothers of children with Zika Congenital Syndrome).  There were three different thematic working groups: (1) diagnostics, technological innovation, and data sharing; (2) virus transmission (vector and non-vector); and (3) clinical studies. I moderated the second one and it was an opportunity to discuss some of my research questions with scientists from different fields, scientific communicators, and stakeholders. Based on the reflections and discussions elaborated during this workshop, we wrote a document pinpointing guidelines and strategies to address the uncertainties and repercussions of the Zika epidemic in Brazil. With part of the material discussed during the working group I am also writing an article with anthropologist Carolina Nogueira and historian Gabriel Lopes about how prevention efforts in Brazil have zeroed in on vector control even though Zika can also be transmitted through sex, blood transfusion, and breastfeeding; we offer an analysis of the epistemological conditions and the political consequences of this focus on the mosquito in Brazilian public policies.

Besides conducting my dissertation research, I tried to use my time in Brazil to establish and strengthen collaborations with scholars and stakeholders based in the country. I am currently working on a co-authored chapter with Brazilian historian Gabriel Lopes. The book, Framing Epidemic Villains: Histories of Disease Hosts and Vectors, addresses the history of the emergence and transformation of epidemiological framings of non-human disease vectors and hosts across the globe. Our chapter examines the mosquito Aedes aegypti’s centenary historical trajectory in Brazil through three epidemic moments (Yellow Fever, Dengue, and Zika) to show how, although there is a continuity of the mosquito as the villain, the epidemiological and political meanings of these virus-mosquito-human interactions significantly change.
